title.narrative: Humanitarian support to UNICEF country programs 2013

description.narrative: Stöd till UNICEFs humanitära landprogram. Stödet inkluderar sektorer som hälsa, nutrition, skyddsfrågor, vatten, sanitet och hygien samt utbildning i krissituationer. Länderna stödet riktar sig till är stora mottagare av humanitärt stöd och inkluderar både väpnade konflikter och naturkatastrofer.

Support to UNICEFs humanitarian country programs. The support includes all the relvant sectors UNICEF is working in; water and sanitation; health; nutrition; protection and education for the most vulnerable groups.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: In 2013, UNICEF worked with partners at all levels, across regions and countries to promote the rights of children in humanitarian emergencies, to ensure that they have access to health care services, adequate nutrition, basic education, HIV and AIDS prevention and treatment, and child protection. Some results achieved are summarized, as follows: In Kenya, UNICEF contributed to increased access for children to treatment against acute malnutrition, with the number of facilities implementing high impact interventions increasing from 976 in 2012 to 1,082 in 2013. UNICEF also secured access to safe drinking water for 200,000 and improved sanitation facilities and hygiene promotion messages reaching over 650,000 people. UNICEF’s humanitarian assistance program in Afghanistan was vital in filling gaps in supply provision, implementation of community management of acute malnutrition programme in the targeted provinces, and monitoring and building capacity of health facilities and community-level partners. UNICEF’s nutrition program reached more vulnerable mothers and children than expected exceeding its planned targets of the number of: - treated children under 5 for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM); - children between 6 and 23 months provided with micronutrient supplementation; and - pregnant and lactating women provided with information on breastfeeding, complementary feeding and WASH promotion. Furthermore, UNICEF yielded unexpectedly positive results in its humanitarian response work in Myanmar’s Rakhine state. UNICEF, for instance, surpassed its target of providing 10,600 children between 6-59 months with multi-micronutrient sprinkles by fourfold – reaching 40,223 children. UNICEF exceeded its target of giving 4,600 pregnant and lactating women multi-nutrient tablets by threefold – benefitting 12,134 women. UNICEF also provided therapeutic feeding to 2,613 children between 6-59 months suffering from SAM and supplementary feeding to 5,530 children between 6 and 59 months suffering from moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), exceeding UNICEF’s targets fourfold, respectively. Additionally, UNICEF and its partners spearheaded the polio pilot immunization campaign, which covered 300,000 children across Rakhine state. These unexpected results are mainly attributed to UNICEF’s partnership with a local NGO - Myanmar Health Assistants Association (MHAA) - that was widely accepted among Rakhine’s Buddhist and Muslim communities, and thus possessed unfettered access to hard-to-reach areas. In the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK), UNICEF successfully provided many vulnerable communities in remote areas access to safe water through the provision of water and hygiene kits, water purification tablets and various educational kits. As a result, around 30,150 households – 132,160 people gained 24-hour access to safe drinking water. Moreover, UNICEF’s health programs, which also involved organizing the Child Health Days (CHD), benefited around 1,76 million children under five. As a part of the CHD, 1,025,433 children between 24 and 59 months were dewormed and 1,524,804 children aged 6-59 months received two doses of vitamin A, both of which reduced DPRK’s child morbidity and mortality rates. UNICEF’ also took part in a joint UN rapid assessment mission where it helped distribute health kits to victims of the July/August 13 flood emergency, benefitting an additional 80,000 flood-affected people and providing 7,110 children under five with essential medicines.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
